Celebrating International Womenâ€™s Day

By Hannah Boyle

Orla McAndrew reflects on this important day and speaks to other editors and writers about who inspires them

Splice

When we think of scientific breakthroughs, we tend to credit a single person with the discovery or invention; that is, if our association goes at all beyond an anonymous group of scientists in a laboratory somewhere

Toy Story 3

"Whaaat? The Gypsy Kings version?" queries Chris Evans as the Spanish Octet's 'You've Got A Friend In Me' blares from his Radio 2 show. Well amigos, all becomes clear upon viewing Pixar's latest offering, the atomic bomb of action that is <em>Toy Story 3</em>

Best served chilled: The Big Chill 2010 review

When it comes to festivals I keep my expectations low. I fully expect to spend a weekend semi-homeless in an oversized plastic-bag coffin lacking any form of hygiene; a personal hell only transcended by the occasional live performance and temporary alcoholism. Hence discovering that The Big Chill offers every modern convenience was akin to a child from a deprived-upbringing being welcomed into a (really middle class) foster home

Anne Boleyn

Howard Brenton's exhilarant <em>Anne Boleyn</em> provides a refreshing addition to The Globe's potentially dry summer season, Kings & Rogues (Thumbnail credit Miranda Raison in Anne Boleyn by Howard Brenton. Photo credit: Manuel Harlan)

Charm//Offensive

Suitable for sketch show veterans or those (like myself) who are not attracted to the work of 'comedians', <em>Charm//Offensive</em> offers exactly what its edgy label presents (Thumbnail credit Image credit: Greg Bartlett)

Clubbed to Death

By James Bithell

Earlier this week York's dear Club Salvation, the pubescent hub of the University's nightlife, fell victim to what the hilarious scallywags of the Westboro Baptist Church might term a 'God Smack', as fire sent from the heavens enveloped its upper floors

Into-Flora

Jewellery curator Kath Libbert discusses her latest exhibition (Thumbnail credit Artist Natalya Pinchuk's work is all about growth: Number Two Growth. All images copyright Kath Libbert Gallery.)

1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces

It is said that 'interactive art' is for children. After a trip to the Victoria and Albert Museum's current exhibition 1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces, I can only beg to differ (Thumbnail credit 'Ark' by Rintala Eggertsson Architects)

A World Observed

A World Observed is the first major retrospective of London- based photographer Dorothy Bohm, now widely recognised as one of the doyennes of British photography (Thumbnail credit Lisbon, Portugal, 1963. Photograph by Dorothy Bohm)

That Face

Shocking is a completely inadequate word to use when describing Polly Stenham's two-act debut 'tragi-comedy' (Thumbnail credit Frances Barber as Martha)

Inception

There are not many films that manage to comprehensively warp reality with a sophistication and subtlety to rival that of The Matrix, but Inception may just be one of them

Staging an Intervention

Acclaimed artist Susan Stockwell talks to Beth Walton about sending art out into the public arena (Thumbnail credit Photography by Shannon Tofts)

Sean Scully: Works from the 1980s

Few things bug me more than bad grammar (Thumbnail credit Sean Scully, Without, 1988)

Alice Neel: Painted Truths

There is something almost frightening walking into the Whitechapel Gallery's new retrospective on Alice Neel

90s Comeback Bands and Pubescent Nostalgia: The Nouse Reading and Leeds Festival Guide 2010

Ah Reading and Leeds festival. You are the obnoxious, pubescent, lairy younger brother to Glastonbury

Exposed: Voyeurism, Surveillance & the Camera

In a desperate attempt to escape the oppressive muggy heat of July in London, I have begun to seek solace in the cool and assuredly calming spaces of its art galleries

Louise Bourgeois dies aged 98

On May 29th 2010 it was announced that Louise Bourgeois, world-renowned sculptor and artist had passed away aged 98 from a heart attack (Thumbnail credit Maman, Collection Tate Modern, London, 1999; Copyright: Marcus Leith)

Bepo

Perhaps one method of defining art is as something which becomes more than the sum of its parts

Kodac Kulture

Kodac Kulture the third and final exhibition of term to open at The Norman Rea last week completes the galleries programme of interactive and student friendly shows for summer

The Sanctuary

The Sanctuary was recommended to me as somewhere pleasant, yet not too pricey, when I had a friend to stay and needed somewhere reasonably nice

Wine

You've finished exams and essays and have the prospect of a long and unproductive summer ahead

Greenberg

Success for up-and-coming American writer/directors is a hit-and-miss business. This month's The Brothers Bloom was generally regarded as a letdown compared to Rian Johnson's first film, Brick

Pub

"Students weren't welcome here before," said the cheerful landlady as she pulled my pint of Timothy Taylor's

The Killer Inside Me

The sudden reputation for provocative, misogynistic brutality earned by Michael Winterbottom's latest release may have led to comparisons with Lars von Trier's Antichrist, but The Killer Inside Me's impact - such as it is - doesn't compare

Matisyahu

Having just released third LP 'Light' in the UK, Matisyahu talks to Mia de Graaf (Thumbnail credit Matisyahu relaxingwith his beard)

Pumping Iron

With effortless charm and less than perfect English, Arnold Schwarzenegger explains how he undermines his opponents in the 1975 Mr Olympia contest: "Franco is pretty smart, but Franco's a child. He comes to me for advices. So it's not hard for me to give him the wrong advices"

Never mind romcoms, make your first date a trip to Martyrs or Antichrist

The date movie is perhaps the worst genre Hollywood has to offer. So vast is the gulf between Valentine's Day, The Bounty Hunter and films someone in full possession of their mental faculties would actually want to see, that one must seek out other entertainment

Future Sounds

(Thumbnail credit Ghostpoet)

Trampled Under Hoof

Tom Killingbeck cross-examines cosmic collective Chrome Hoof

Rob Ryan on his growing art and design empire

By James Bithell

Rob Ryan has no problem with his art going on a pair of knickers. Beth Walton asks what it's like to be the main man behind his growing art and design empire
